slide.title: Document/Literal

list.title: Differences between Document and RPC styles

blurb.html: Note the differences (below) between an RPC call and a Document message. RPC calls will have a "function" element around the parameters, type data (xsi:type attribute), and an encodingStyle attribute in the envelope.

slide.example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<SOAP-ENV:Envelope xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:SOAP-ENC="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" xmlns:ns4="http://soapinterop.org/"
SOAP-ENV:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" >
<SOAP-ENV:Body>
<ns4:echoString> <inputString xsi:type="xsd:string">this is a test</inputString> </ns4:echoString>
</SOAP-ENV:Body> </SOAP-ENV:Envelope>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<SOAP-ENV:Envelope xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:SOAP-ENC="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" > <SOAP-ENV:Body>
<ns1:echoStringParam xmlns:ns1="http://soapinterop.org/xsd"> this is a test </ns1:echoStringParam>
</SOAP-ENV:Body> </SOAP-ENV:Envelope>
